text.p: Following are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The National Assembly (lower house) once again failed to decide how to go about the president's directives for the eradication of corruption.
- Karachi suffered a massive power breakdown that plunged almost the entire city into total darkness. Power was restored after two hours.
- Pakistan on Saturday strongly resisted a "declaration on good governance" likely to be adopted late Sunday at the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

- After spending more than five billion rupees in the last six years to control population growth, the rate at which the population is growing has come down to 2.8 percent in 1995 from 3.1 percent in 1990, an official report said.
- Tajekistan's minister of transport said the central Asian states would fulfil their trade needs through the highways of Pakistan which would ultimately turn Pakistan into a great trade centre.

- The ministry of finance has begun preparing a strategy to handle any financial crisis in the country if talks with the International Monetary Fund for disbursement of the stalled standby loan fails.
- Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has left for the U.S. to address the U.N. session.
- The National Assembly (lower house) has offered prayers for Afghan's former president Dr Najibullah Khan.
- Pakistan will receive the first-ever consignment of T-80 Russian tanks from Ukraine in January, Defence Minister Aftab Shaaban Mirani said.
- The government has agreed to the formation of parliament's select committees to suggest ways for curbing corruption.
- Foreign Minister Assef Ahmed Ali has said Pakistan is closely following developments in Afghanistan.
